oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinical and Experimental Studies with Verapamil in the Dog
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hamlin, Robert L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: calcium channel blockers
dogs
oral administration
verapamil
myocardial contractility
heart rate
atrial tachycardia
atrial fibrillation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Calcium channel blockers have been used with increasing frequency in human medicine as antihypertensivies, antianginals, antiarrhythmics, and to treat hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (1). Although many studies have been conducted using dogs as experimental animals being given calcium channel blockers parenterally (2), the primary use in veterinary medicine will probably require administration of these agents by the oral route. Because little information is available describing the effects of verapamil--the most commonly used calcium channel blocker--on myocardial contractility and heart rate, and determining time from administration orally to peak effect and duration of effect (3), this study was conducted on healthy, chronically-instrumented dogs. Parallel with these studies, 27 dogs afflicted with either atrial tachycardia or atrial fibrillation with rapid response, were given verapamil as therapy.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: AAVPT Biennial Symposia; Fifth Biennial Symposium; 89-96
